In the present study, the textural characteristics and catalytic efficiency of the NiO(x)-MgO solid-solution catalysts (x = 10,15,20, and 25 wt.%) were determined in CO2 reforming of propane. All samples were fabricated by the simple mechanochemical preparation route. The chemicophysical characteristics of the synthesized catalysts were determined using XRD, BET, H2-TPR, TPO, and SEM exams. The obtained results demonstrated that the physicochemical properties and catalytic activity of the samples were affected with the increment in NiO content, which is assigned to the change in the concentration of active sites and improvement of the reduction features. The NiO(25)-MgO catalyst was selected as the sample with the highest activity, and the effect of the operating factors and calcination temperature were studied over this catalyst. Also, the TPO analysis showed that the whisker carbon was formed on the spent catalyst and the sample with 25 wt.% Ni possessed the highest amount of deposited carbon. Moreover, the initial catalytic activity of all catalysts was not changed during 300 min time on stream. Graphical abstract Image, graphical abstract Keywords NiO-MgO catalyst Mechanochemical preparation method Propane dry reforming Whisker carbon 1 Introduction Synthesis gas is a mixture of hydrogen and carbon monoxide, which has received remarkable attention in industrial applications such as petrochemical products and building blocks for chemical components [1]. Among the methods of synthesis gas production, reforming of light hydrocarbons has a special place due to the relatively low produced H2/CO, which is suitable in olefin and GTL fuels productions [2,3]. On the other side, propane (C3H8) along with methane and ethane, are the major components of natural gas, and its reforming is carried out in lower operating temperatures than methane. Propane has higher carbon atom content than methane and ethane, and therefore, it can produce more surface carbon species. Moreover, propane can be transported and stored easily in liquid form [4]. However, various researches have been focused on the major ways for hydrogen production via propane reforming reactions. In this regard, propane dry reforming (PDR, Eq. (1)) is very noticeable, owning to its industrial applications and environmental aspects [2,5]. CO2, as one of the primary sources of greenhouse gases (GHG), is utilized in this process, and thus, the emissions of GHG are reduced in the atmosphere. On the other side, by removing steam from the reforming feedstock, more energy is also saved [6]. (1) C 3 H 8 ( g ) + 3 C O 2 ( g ) → 6 C O ( g ) + 4 H 2 ( g ) Δ H ∘ 298 = 644.8 ( k J . m o l − 1 ) Noble (such as Pd, Pt, Ru, Ag) and transition metals (such as Ni, Fe, Co, Si) have been utilized in PDR reaction. Conventionally, this reaction is performed over the Ni-based catalysts at temperatures above 500 °C due to the endothermic nature of the PDR process [7–10]. For instance, Karuppiah and Mok [11] synthesized the Ni/γ-Al2O3 with a high specific surface area (138 m2.g−1) by impregnation method, and the prepared sample was applied in PDR reaction. They reported that the propane conversion improved from 60 to 100% with increasing the operating temperatures from 540 to 600 °C. However, sintering and coke formation are the primary reasons for the rapid deactivation of Ni-based catalysts. Carbon formation occurs over the catalyst surface through the propane decomposition (Eq. 2) and Boudouard (Eq. 3) reactions. (2) C 3 H 8 ( g ) → C H 4 ( g ) + 2 H 2 ( g ) + 2 C ( s ) (3) 2 C O ( g ) → C O 2 ( g ) + C ( s ) In this case, remarkable efforts have been performed to design an efficient catalyst with high resistance against coke formation. Apart from the single metal oxides, fabrication of the bi-/tri metallic catalysts and reduction of nickel crystallite size are the suitable alternative to improve the activity and stability of the nickel catalysts. The smaller nickel particles restricted the carbon deposition and increased the catalytic activity via the provision of the more active sites for adsorption and reaction [12,13]. It was reported that the existence of Fe in bi-metallic Ni-Fe catalyst increased the catalytic stability and lessened the coke formation due to the redox features of Fe [14]. In another literature, Ni/γ-Al2O3, Ni-Co/γ-Al2O3, and Ni-Mo/γ-Al2O3 were prepared by impregnation technique, and the synthesized catalysts were employed in PDR reaction [15]. The authors claimed that the Ni-Mo/γ-Al2O3 has a lower carbon dioxide consumption rate and higher product (H2/CO) molar ratios. Furthermore, this catalyst possessed the best activity and stability during 4300 min time on stream. In contrast, the monometallic nickel and Ni-Co/γ-Al2O3 were deactivated after 1800 min time on stream. However, the use of basic supports such as MgO and CaO can significantly decrease coke formation. These components accelerate the reverse Boudouard reaction via more CO2 chemisorption [16]. For instance, the NiO-MgO-SiO2 catalysts with various percentage of nickel were utilized in C3H8 dry reforming and the results indicated that the formation of NiO-MgO solid solution and basic features of magnesium oxide are the essential factors in the high stability of the synthesized catalysts [17]. Co-precipitation, impregnation, sol-gel, combustion, and hydrothermal are the main routes for synthesizing the transition materials [18–22]. In recent years, the solid-state mechanochemical preparation method as a facile and low-cost route with high efficiency in short preparation time is suitable for replacing conventional methods and has received considerable attention from different researchers [23]. Ni-Al2O3 and Ni-Cr2O3 were prepared by this method and utilized in low-temperature CO2- methanation [24,25], or Cu-Fe-V-O system was synthesized with a solid-state method, and textural features of the prepared samples were investigated in methanol steam reforming [26]. In these years, the use of plasma technology (especially non-thermal plasma) has been received more attention in reforming reactions. Radicals with high activity and atoms are produced through the feed converted by the high energetic plasma electrons. In this process, the electron temperatures are higher than molecules, atoms, photons, and radicals [27–29]. Non-thermal plasma could remarkably enhance the efficiency of reactions. For instance, Wang et al. [30] performed plasma catalytic methane dry reforming over the Ni/AC and reported that the highest catalytic activity was obtained when dry reforming was carried out under plasma combined with Ni/AC catalyst. The current study was focused on the fabrication of NiO-MgO catalyst with solid-state mechanochemical preparation method by varying the nickel content to achieve a catalyst with high efficiency and low coke deposition in PDR reaction. 2 Materials and methods 2.1 Synthesis of materials NiO(x)-MgO (NM) catalysts with various nickel loadings were prepared based on the mechanochemical preparation method. Briefly, desirable amounts of Ni(NO3)2.6H2O (Merck, 99%), Mg(NO3)2.6H2O (Merck, 99%), and (NH4)2CO3 (LOBACHEMIE, 99%) were mixed in an agate mortar at ambient temperature. After 20 min, the pasty mixture was obtained due to the release of the OH groups and precipitation of metal nitrate precursors. The obtained product was dried at 100 °C for 24 h and finally calcined in an electrical furnace at 500 °C for 3 h with a heating rate of 3 °C/min. 2.2 Catalyst characterization Powder X-ray diffraction patterns (XRD) of the samples were obtained using the PANalytical X'Pert-Pro instrument with Cu-Kα radiation operated at 45 kV and 40 mA. The specific surface area, adsorption/desorption isotherm, and pore features were specified using a Belsorp mini II instrument at the boiling point of liquid nitrogen (-196 °C). A gas chromatograph with a thermal conductivity detector (TCD) was applied to accomplish the temperature-programmed reduction (H2-TPR) technique of the calcined samples. For this test, 0.1 g of the calcined catalyst was placed in a U-shaped quartz reactor (I.D. = 7 mm). The reducing gas flow (15 ml.min−1, 5% H2 balanced with Ar) was introduced into the reactor, and the processing temperature raised from room temperature to 900 °C with a heating rate of 10 °C/min. A SEM FEI Quanta 200 device was used to investigate the morphological characteristics of the fresh and spent samples. To study the amount of carbon deposited on the catalyst surface, temperature-programmed oxidation (TPO) analysis was applied using a similar instrument as explained for the TPR test. In this regard, an oxidizing gas stream (15 ml.min−1, 5% O2 balanced with He) was passed over the sample, and the temperature raised from 25 to 900 °C. 2.3 Reaction study To examine the catalytic performance of the samples, PDR reaction was done in a fixed-bed reactor (I.D. = 7 mm, L = 700 mm). In this regard, 0.2 g of the calcined catalyst with specified size (30–50 μm) was loaded into the quartz reactor, which was situated vertically inside an electrical furnace, and the K-type thermocouple was embedded under the catalyst bed to ensure the reaction was carried out isothermally. Prior to the test, the catalyst was reduced in-situ under 30 ml.min−1 hydrogen flow at 800 °C for 2 h. CO2 reforming was accomplished by feeding the flow containing propane and carbon dioxide (C3H8:CO2 = 1:3) with a GHSV value of 30,000 (ml.h−1.g−1 cat). The catalytic activity was investigated in the temperature range of 550–750 °C under atmospheric pressure. The analysis of the products during PDR reaction was done by an online gas chromatograph (YL, 6100 GC) with a micro TCD and Carboxen 1010 column. The C3H8 and CO2 conversion, H2 yield, and C-containing product selectivity were determined according to the following equations Eqs. (4)–(6). (4) C 3 H 8 conversion ( % ) = moles of C 3 H 8 converted moles of C 3 H 8 in the feed × 100 (5) H 2 yield ( % ) = moles of H 2 produced total moles of H 2 in the feed × 100 (6) A selectivity ( % ) = moles of C in product A total moles of C in the products × 100 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Textural features of the NiO(x)-MgO catalysts The X-ray diffraction patterns of the as-fabricated catalysts with different weight percentage of NiO are displayed in Fig. 1 a. As can be seen, all calcined catalysts have nanocrystalline structure. The detected diffraction patterns at 2θ = 37.2°, 43.2°, 62.5°, 75°, and 79° are assigned to the NiO {JCPDS: 01-001-1239} and MgO {JCPDS: 01-001-1235} phases [31,32]. However, the formation of NiO-MgO solid solution and placement of Ni2+ and Mg2+ in the equal lattice of the NiO-MgO solid solution makes it difficult to distinguish them from each other. Furthermore, the patterns with intensified peaks were observed in the samples with higher active metal contents, which is related to the increment of the agglomeration degree of nickel oxide species. The nitrogen adsorption-desorption isotherms and pore characteristics of the NiO-MgO catalysts with different nickel oxide loadings are illustrated in Fig. 1b and 1c, respectively. The obtained isotherms revealed that all samples have similar isotherms, and based on the IUPAC classification, they show type II with an H3 hysteresis loop. However, these isotherm and hysteresis loop is commonly found in macroporous samples with non-uniform shapes and proportions. It is worth noting that the hysteresis loop was formed at lower P/P0 values when the nickel content was increased from 10 to 25 wt.%, which is related to the improvement of the BET area in samples with higher NiO contents. Moreover, as shown in Fig. 1c, the pore size distribution profiles demonstrated that all catalysts have mesoporous and macroporous structures in the wide range of 10–70 nm. Table 1 showed that the textural properties of the NiO-MgO catalysts with various nickel loadings. It was observed that the SBET, pore-volume, and pore size increased from 16.9 to 20.56 m2.g−1, 0.064 to 0.081 cm3.g−1, and 15.35 to 15.91 nm with increasing the NiO loading from 10 to 25 wt.%, respectively. Furthermore, the NiO crystallite size, determined by the Scherrer equation (Eq. 7), revealed that the increment in weight percentage of NiO resulted in the lower crystallite size. (7) D = 0.9 λ β cos θ In this equation, λ is the wavelength (nm), β is the full width at half maximum (rad), and θ is the diffraction angle (degree). To examine the reducibility features of the synthesized catalysts, the H2-TPR technique was carried out, and the obtained results are presented in Fig. 2 . The catalysts with 10 and 15 wt.% of NiO show one reduction peak in the temperature range of 400-700 °C, which is attributed to the weak interaction between nickel oxide and magnesium oxide. However, this phenomenon caused the improvement in Ni dispersion and sintering prohibition during the reaction test [33,34]. Furthermore, two reduction peaks were identified for the samples with 20 and 25 wt.%, which is related to the reduction of NiO species with weak and strong interaction with the MgO. When the nickel loading increased from 10 to 25 wt.%, the maximum reduction temperature of the first reduction peak transferred to lower values, confirming the reducibility of the samples with higher nickel loadings was improved at low temperatures. 3.2 Catalytic performance of the NiO(x)-MgO catalysts The PDR reaction was carried out over the synthesized samples, and C3H8 and CO2 conversion diagrams as a function of operating temperatures are presented in Fig. 3 a and b. Due to the endothermic nature of the PDR process, the propane and carbon dioxide conversion improved with rising the reaction temperature from 550 to 750 °C. Furthermore, rising the nickel loadings from 10 to 25 wt.% increased the reactant conversion. The highest C3H8 and CO2 conversions of about 99 and 100% were obtained in the sample containing 25 wt.% NiO at 750 °C, respectively. Fig. 3c describes the product (H2/CO) molar ratio versus temperature for all calcined catalysts. The stoichiometric value of the product molar ratio is 0.66 for PDR reaction. However, the obtained results revealed that the H2/CO molar ratio for all samples increased with the increase of the operating temperature and nickel loading, but these obtained values were lower than the theoretical H2/CO. This is because that the side reactions take place simultaneously with the main PDR reaction. The H2/CO ratio of the NiO(25)-MgO catalyst was reached 0.65, which is near to the stoichiometric value. Methane as the major undesired by-product in the PDR reaction competes with hydrogen and carbon monoxide, which is produced mainly by propane cracking (Eq. (2)). For this reason, the CH4 selectivity for all samples was determined, and the outcomes are depicted in Fig. 3d. The remarkable value of methane has been produced at 750 °C, and it lessened to close zero at about 600 °C. This trend is in agreement with the obtained patterns for propane and carbon dioxide conversion. Fig. 3e shows the short-time stability of C3H8 at 750 °C for all catalysts. The results confirmed that all synthesized samples (except NiO(10)-MgO) have relatively high stability without any remarkable change in initial propane conversion during the 300 min reaction period. However, the powerful interaction between Ni and MgO and the formation of NiO-MgO solid solution has caused the samples to have high resistance against sintering and coke deposition. Moreover, the presence of MgO as a basic site along with NiO decreased the carbon formation over the catalyst surface. The products (H2 and CO) yield versus reaction temperature over the samples with various nickel contents is depicted in Fig. 4 a and b. As expected, the hydrogen yield increased with an increment of operating temperature for all samples. It is owning to having a higher propane conversion at high temperatures. Therefore, the catalyst with 25 wt.% of NiO resulted in higher H2 yield comparing the other samples. It is worth noting that the H2/CO molar ratio for this sample was also higher than others, indicating more progress toward other ways of hydrogen production, such as C3H8 cracking during the main reaction might have occurred. Furthermore, a similar trend was observed for CO yield. However, the CO yield value was higher than the H2 yield for each sample, especially at low temperatures due to the CO formation and H2 consumption in the reverse water gas shift (RWGS) reaction at the temperature range of 550–650 °C. 3.3 Temperature-programmed oxidation analysis of the NiO(x)-MgO catalysts In order to study the coke formation, the TPO analysis was performed over the spent NiO(x)-MgO catalysts with various NiO loadings. As displayed in Fig. 5 , whisker-type carbon was formed over all spent catalysts in the temperature range of 500–900 °C. It was reported that this kind of carbon does not change the initial catalytic activity, but it may cause the reactor pressure drop owning to the blockage of the reactor [35]. This theory is in agreement with our obtained results. However, the oxidation peak area increased with the increment of the nickel oxide content, which is related to the increase of the deposited coke on the catalyst surface in samples with higher NiO loadings. Consequently, the catalyst with 25 wt.% of NiO possessed the highest deposited coke due to the lowest nickel dispersion. 3.4 Influence of calcination temperature Calcination temperature is a crucial factor, which could significantly affect the chemicophysical features and efficiency of the catalysts. Fig. 6 a depicts the XRD pattern profiles of the samples with different calcination temperatures. It is seen that the change in calcination temperatures did not alter the catalyst crystallinity. Furthermore, raising the calcination temperature from 400 to 600 °C increased the intensity of the diffraction peak. The physisorption isotherms and distribution pores of the samples with different calcination temperatures are shown in Fig. 6b and 6c, respectively. The results indicated that all samples have type II isotherm with an H3 hysteresis loop. However, the increment of calcination temperatures has resulted in the formation of P/P0 at higher values, which is assigned to the sintering of particles and decrease the BET area at higher temperatures, Table 2 . Furthermore, the pore characteristics showed that the higher calcination temperatures shifted the pore distribution profiles to lower ranges. The physicochemical properties of the NiO(25)-MgO catalysts with various calcination temperatures are reported in Table 2. As stated above, the decrease of SBET and pore volume was observed from 26.13 to 18.93 m2.g−1 and 0.103 to 0.068 cm3.g−1 with the rise of calcination temperatures from 400 to 600 °C, respectively. Furthermore, the crystallite size of NiO relatively increased in samples calcined at high temperatures. The impression of calcination temperature on the reducibility of the NiO(25)-MgO catalyst was examined by the H2-TPR test, and the profiles are illustrated in Fig. 7 . It can be observed that all catalysts have two reduction peaks in the temperature region of 500–800 °C, which is associated with the nickel interaction with magnesium [13]. However, the reduction peak intensity for the sample calcined at 600 °C was higher than the other calcined catalysts. Also, the increment of calcination temperatures from 400 to 600 °C shifted the maximum reduction temperature to higher values, confirming the lower reduction degree at low temperatures, which could negatively affect the catalytic activity. SEM analysis of the NiO(25)-MgO catalyst calcined at different temperatures are displayed in Fig. 8 (a–c). owning to the sintering of species at high calcination temperatures, the more agglomerated particles were formed with rising the calcination temperature from 400 to 600 °C. The C3H8 and CO2 conversions of the NiO(25)-MgO catalysts calcined at several temperatures are shown in Fig. 9 a and 9b, respectively. Both conversions decreased with the rise of calcination temperature from 400 to 600 °C, owing to the reduction of specific surface area, lower reducibility degree, and sintering of particles at higher calcination temperatures. Moreover, the yield of H2 and CO was also evaluated for the catalyst calcined at 400, 500, and 600 °C, and the diagrams are shown in Fig. 9c and d. A similar trend with the conversion diagrams was seen for the yield of hydrogen and carbon monoxide. The yield of products improved by reducing the calcination temperature. Also, the incidence of RWGS reaction has caused the CO yield to be higher than the H2 yield value in all calcination temperatures. 3.5 Influence of processing conditions Fig. 10 a describes the effect of GHSV on the propane and carbon dioxide conversions of the NiO(25)-MgO catalyst calcined at 500 °C. For this test, the feed ratio (CO2:C3H8) and operating reaction temperature were remained constant at 3:1 and 700 °C, respectively. Based on the obtained results, the C3H8 and CO2 conversions were reduced by the increment of the GHSV value from 21,000 to 48,000 (ml/h.gcat). However, the decrease in residence time and amount of adsorbed reactants are the significant reasons for the decrement of C3H8 and CO2 conversions. Feed (CO2/C3H8) variation effect on the catalytic activity of the present sample was also determined at constant GHSV value and operating temperature, and the results are depicted in Fig. 10b. The results revealed that the C3H8 conversion improved and CO2 conversion reduced with the increase of reactant ratio (CO2/C3H8) from 1:1 to 7:1. This phenomenon has occurred as a result of the existence of excess carbon dioxide in this reaction. The effect of the change of the reduction temperature on the catalytic activity of the selected catalyst was also evaluated, and the results are shown in Fig. 11 a and b. Increasing the reduction temperature in the range of 600–800 °C enhanced the reactant conversion, which is related to the increase of the active site concentration on the surface of sample and higher adsorption of CO2, which can react with propane. Fig. 12 a shows the stability results of the Ni(25)-MgO catalyst. It can be seen that the propane and carbon dioxide conversion were stable during the 500 min time on stream. The overall loss in initial catalytic activity was 1.68 and 2.89% for C3H8 and CO2, respectively. The SEM images of the fresh and spent catalyst were also shown in Fig. 12b and c. However, the whisker-type carbon was detected on the catalyst after the stability test. As stated before, the propane decomposition and Boudouard reaction are responsible for the catalyst deactivation in the PDR process. 4 Conclusion The characteristic properties and catalytic performance of the NiO-MgO catalyst with various NiO contents fabricated by the facile and novel mechanochemical preparation route were evaluated in the propane dry reforming. The results revealed that the increment of NiO loading from 10 to 25 wt.% enhanced the reduction features and specific surface area from 16.90 to 20.56 m2.g−1. Furthermore, the catalytic efficiency was also significantly improved with the rise of nickel loading. The NiO(25)-MgO catalyst possessed the highest activity in terms of propane and carbon dioxide conversion as well as H2/CO molar ratio and product yields, which could be ascribed to the physicochemical properties and more available active sites. On the other side, the increment of NiO contents has caused more whisker carbon to be formed over the spent catalysts. Also, the influence of calcination temperature and processing factors was studied on the chemicophysical properties and catalytic activity of the NiO(25)-MgO catalyst. The calcination effect showed that the rise of calcination temperatures from 400 to 600 °C lessened the BET area, catalyst reduction, and initial propane conversion owning to the sintering of particles at higher calcination temperatures. Furthermore, the operating conditions revealed that the increment of GHSV value from 21,000 to 48,000 (ml.h−1.g−1 cat) and CO2/C3H8 molar ratio from 1:1 to 7:1 lessened the propane conversion. coredata.dc:description: In the present study, the textural characteristics and catalytic efficiency of the NiO(x)-MgO solid-solution catalysts (x = 10,15,20, and 25 wt.%) were determined in CO2 reforming of propane. All samples were fabricated by the simple mechanochemical preparation route. The chemicophysical characteristics of the synthesized catalysts were determined using XRD, BET, H2-TPR, TPO, and SEM exams. The obtained results demonstrated that the physicochemical properties and catalytic activity of the samples were affected with the increment in NiO content, which is assigned to the change in the concentration of active sites and improvement of the reduction features. The NiO(25)-MgO catalyst was selected as the sample with the highest activity, and the effect of the operating factors and calcination temperature were studied over this catalyst. Also, the TPO analysis showed that the whisker carbon was formed on the spent catalyst and the sample with 25 wt.% Ni possessed the highest amount of deposited carbon. Moreover, the initial catalytic activity of all catalysts was not changed during 300 min time on stream.
coredata.dc:title: Propane dry reforming over highly active NiO-MgO solid solution catalyst for synthesis gas production
